title: Add high level summary at the top of crates/modules in the book
body:
[crates and modules](http://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/book/crates-and-modules.html) has a lot of info which is buried deep in the text. It'd be good to have a few major points that the text covers highlighted at the top, perhaps with bullet points or something.
- The crate is the compilation unit; modules are subordinate to the crate
- One cargo unit typically contains up to 2 crates:
  - a `lib.rs` crate for the library
  - a `main.rs` crate for the binary
- Interaction across crates is handled via `extern crate` command
- `mod foo.rs` and `mod foo { ... }` are equivalent except:
  - `mod { ... }` puts the contents inside the braces
  - `mod foo.rs;` requests `cargo` find the contents in either:
    - `foo.rs`
    - `foo/mod.rs`
- Modules are private by default. Make them public with `pub`
- Namespace importation is handled via `use`:
  - Relative paths:
    - `use foo::bar`;: use `bar` inside of `foo`
    - `use foo::bar::baz;`: use `baz` inside of `bar` inside of `foo`
    - `use foo::{bar, baz};`: use `bar` and `baz` which are both inside `foo`
    - `use foo::*;`: use all names inside `foo`
    - `use foo::{self, bar};`: use `bar` inside `foo` and module `foo`
  - Absolute paths:
    - `use ::foo::bar;` use `bar` inside of `foo` which is at the crate root
  - Renames are allowed:
    - `use foo as tofu;`: use `foo` under the name `tofu`

I tried to skim the page looking for all the major points. Maybe I grabbed too many but if this table was at the top, it might help people not miss things so easily. Probably would be useful other places too.
